bio: I am a Postdoctoral Researcher at Stanford Graduate School of Business, working with Professor Michele J. Gelfand. My research examines human prosocial behavior—including trust, cooperation, and charitable giving—and punishment across cultures, investigating how social structures shape interpersonal behaviors through multi-level analyses of individual and group dynamics.

I received my Ph.D. in Social Psychology from Beijing Normal University (2024), where I studied under Professor Kou Yu. My dissertation explored how economic inequality influences philanthropy. Previously, I was a Postdoctoral Researcher at Vrije Universiteit Amsterdam with Professor Daniel Balliet.

research.intro: My research interests lie at the intersection of social psychology, cultural psychology, and behavioral economics. I am particularly interested in understanding how macro-level social structures—such as economic inequality—shape individual prosocial behaviors like trust, cooperation, and charitable giving across different cultural contexts.

areas.title: Economic Inequality and Prosocial Behavior
areas.description: Investigating how economic inequality influences charitable giving, trust, and cooperation. My dissertation examined the psychological mechanisms through which inequality affects philanthropy, including the mediating role of interpersonal trust.

areas.title: Cross-Cultural Psychology
areas.description: Examining how cultural factors shape prosocial behavior and punishment across societies. This includes multi-level investigations of how social structures influence interpersonal behaviors through individual and group dynamics.

areas.title: Quantitative Methods in Psychology
areas.description: Applying advanced methodological approaches including longitudinal modeling (MLM, LGCM, GMM), experimental designs using economic games, structural equation modeling, and computational methods to study social behavior.
